image.altText: A children's toy bear laying sideways on a floor.

props.synopsis: Documents detailing five years' worth of childcare breaches in the ACT reveal cases of educators slapping children, forcibly shaking them, throwing them, and possessing child exploitation material.

title.children: 'She was slapped': Inappropriate childcare educator discipline exposed

image.altText: The exteior of a modern apartment block.

props.synopsis: Large glazed windows are a popular design flaw in Australian apartments, according to an expert.

title.children: Why apartments with floor-to-ceiling windows are a 'trade-off' in Australia

image.altText: A yellow and purple car impounded by police.

props.synopsis: A major police operation at Summernats has resulted in 19 vehicle seizures, hundreds of traffic offences and multiple arrests.

title.children: Police seize 19 vehicles after dangerous driving at Summernats

image.altText: A close up of a silver pipe bomb

props.synopsis: Eleven explosive devices have been found next to footpaths in the city's north-west in the past two days, ACT police say.

title.children: Police say 11 explosive devices found on Canberra streets

image.altText: A colourful children's toy block lies sideways in front of a colourful abacus.

props.synopsis: Never-before-seen documents reveal reports of sexual abuse, inappropriate educator discipline, and children missing from ACT childcare centres.

title.children: Thousands of documents show behind the scenes of embattled childcare industry

image.altText: Woman with bob haircut sits on a purple chair in an empty doctor waiting room.

props.synopsis: The percentage of GP clinics fully bulk-billing has almost doubled, according to a new report, however, the government says the data cannot be relied on.

title.children: Only 1 in 10 ACT GP clinics are bulk billing despite nationwide increase

image.altText: A composite of luxury jewellery including rings and watches.

props.synopsis: Lawyers say the value of the allegedly stolen luxury goods, including a $5 million Richard Mille watch, is disputed as the case returns to court.

title.children: Two French men to plead guilty over alleged $10m theft in Canberra

image.altText: A satellite image shows a large burnt area and smoke pouring from a fire.

props.synopsis: Hundreds of images captured by an orbiting weather satellite, and stitched together by the ABC, show the scale and destructive force of the Victorian bushfires.

title.children: Piecing together hundreds of satellite images shows the bushfire crisis unfolding

image.altText: Families with candles at a vigil outside a prison

props.synopsis: Venezuela's new leader says political prisoners are being freed, but hundreds remain jailed, with families clinging to hope that America's intervention and ongoing pressure will eventually secure their loved ones' release

title.children: Zaida's son was snatched in the night, she's begging for his release

image.altText: The smoke stacks of the Bayswater power station.

props.synopsis: In a move labelled a sign of the times, energy firm AGL was last week offering customers money to cut use during a heatwave.

title.children: Households 'paid to switch off' as extreme weather stalks power grid

image.altText: A photo compilation of Reza Pahlavi, Hassan Rouhani, and Maryam Rajavi.

props.synopsis: Names frequently raised include an exiled prince, a former president, and the leader of a leftist movement, but experts say no single figure has the power and legitimacy to take control alone.

title.children: An exiled prince and a leftist dissident vie for Iran’s future

image.altText: A smiling older man and woman sit on some rocks near a waterway.

props.synopsis: Struggling to find answers about what happened in the week leading up to her death in hospital, Sue Smith's loved ones say they want hospitals to put more resources into investigating these types of incidents.

title.children: Sue thought she had gastro. She died a week later and her family wants answers

image.altText: Alexis Hutcheon sits on a stair well.

props.synopsis: A major Australian study finds standard antidepressants are not effective for around 20 per cent of people, who may need alternative treatments.

title.children: Antidepressants failing many people, major study reveals

image.altText: A woman's hand holds a phone displaying a number of widgets for various apps.

props.synopsis: More than 4.7 million Australian social media accounts have been deactivated since laws banning children aged under 16 took effect in December, according to data released by the government.

title.children: Millions of accounts culled days after social media ban started, data shows

image.altText: People in military fatigues disembark from a Royal Danish Air Force plane and board busses.

props.synopsis: As European countries send small numbers of troops to Greenland, the White House says their presence will not affect US President Donald Trump's ambitions for the island.

title.children: White House shrugs off presence of European troops in Greenland

image.altText: An old newspaper clipping photo of two men and two women raising drinks.

props.synopsis: With whisky and lollies for sustenance and pigeons their only means of communication, Steve Harris and Doug Fleming crossed Bass Strait in a 4.5m dinghy in 1974.

title.children: Two blokes, whisky and lollies on a 'foolhardy' Bass Strait crossing

image.altText: A close up of a woman's hand holding a cross necklace.

props.synopsis: Documents leaked to the ABC reveal an "apocalyptic Christian cult" is targeting Ballarat, Bendigo, Geelong and Darwin.

title.children: Ex-member says Shincheonji 'cult' spreading across the country

image.altText: A close up image of Kevin Rudd with his hand on his chin.

props.synopsis: Test your knowledge of this week's news cycle here.

title.children: Weekly news quiz: An early departure and an Aussie Golden Globe win

image.altText: A python resting on a straw mat

props.synopsis: It's fair to say when a Brisbane resident woke up to discover a carpet python curled up on top of her she was rattled.

title.children: 'Babe, don't move': Woman wakes up to 2.5-metre python curled up on top of her

image.altText: Anthony Albanese wears a suit and blue tie, and black-rimmed glasses. He stares intently just past the camera.

props.synopsis: Parliament will return early next week to debate new hate speech laws. But what exactly does the legislation include?

title.children: What is in the government's new hate speech laws?

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: The Australian dollar jumps again on potentially more dovish policy from the US Federal Reserve, while Taiwan and the US have struck a major semiconductor deal. Follow the day's events and insights as they happen with our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Aussie dollar nudges 67 US cents, Wall Street up on 'massive' AI chips deal

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Aussie dollar nears 67 US cents on rate expectations

image.altText: Images of tar black spheres found washed up on the sand of Sydney eastern suburbs beaches.

props.synopsis: The NSW Environment Protection Authority identified the Malabar wastewater treatment system as the origin of the debris balls plaguing beaches in Sydney.

title.children: $3bn wastewater overhaul after debris balls on Sydney beaches

image.altText: A woman with her hair up in a pink suit looks directly at the camera.

props.synopsis: A growing number of women in the Northern Territory are travelling interstate to give birth — or leaving the territory altogether — following the sudden closure of the only private hospital maternity ward. Now, the NT's last private obstetrician is closing her practice.

title.children: NT's last private obstetrician walks away as maternity services face collapse

image.altText: A dragonfly resting on a mobile phone with the Wikipedia page for dragonfly on the screen of phone

props.synopsis: Wikipedia is celebrating 25 years of the online encyclopedia and the enormous impact its had, while looking forward to its future. But some controversies from the past refuse to die.

title.children: Wikipedia is 25, but some old fights are still going

image.altText: A man in a suit stands in a playground

props.synopsis: City of Canning Mayor Patrick Hall is awarded a quarter of a million dollars in a lengthy defamation fight with one of his own constituents over a series of social media posts.

title.children: Suburban Perth mayor wins $250,000 in defamation battle with ratepayer

image.altText: A woman wearing a large winter coat protesting and holding her hands up at night.

props.synopsis: Such a move would allow the president to deploy troops to quell persistent protests in the city of Minneapolis, where two shootings connected to immigration crackdowns are fuelling public anger.

title.children: Trump threatens to invoke Insurrection Act over Minnesota anti-ICE protests

image.altText: Storm Hunter yells in celebration while holding racquet

props.synopsis: Storm Hunter books her spot in the main draw of the Australian Open — something that was inconceivable last year as she battled injuries that left her in tears mid-match.

title.children: Teary Hunter says Aus Open berth 'meant the world' after injury heartache

image.altText: Four members of Britpop era band Pulp sit in a studio among instruments and recording equipment

props.synopsis: Pulp had been among the acts prepared to boycott the festival over the cancellation of a slot with the Palestinian-Australian author at Adelaide Writers' Week.

title.children: Pulp agree to Adelaide Festival show after apology to Randa Abdel-Fattah

image.altText: Group of workers in hi-vis, putting sand into bags, on grass ground, houses in background

props.synopsis: Rockhampton is bracing for possible flooding while communities in the already-sodden Gulf Country fear they may be isolated for "a long time to come" as ex-Tropical Cyclone Koji threatens more rain.

title.children: Rockhampton and Gulf Country communities brace for possible flooding

image.altText: A plume of black and grey smoke rises from a hill in the distance, with disposed fridges in the foreground.

props.synopsis: People are being urged to dispose of their batteries properly, after a series of fires at landfills across New South Wales.

title.children: Battery fire at tip could burn for weeks

image.altText: Man in a grey hoodie standing on a beach.

props.synopsis: Up to 500 workers are fighting to recoup pay, super and entitlements after the collapse of a large disability support provider operating in New South Wales.

title.children: Workers lose pay, super as NDIS provider collapses

image.altText: A worker inspects steel products at the Whyalla steelworks.

props.synopsis: The former owner of the Whyalla steelworks, Sanjeev Gupta's OneSteel Manufacturing, owed $18.5 million in royalties when it was forced into administration last year, the ABC can reveal.

title.children: Former Whyalla steelworks' owner's royalties debt revealed

image.altText: Hands and feet are visible as an islander kneels among a swarm of tiny, baby red crabs.

props.synopsis: Wildlife officials on one of Australia's most remote territories are welcoming the final chapter of its famous red crab migration, the return to shore of millions of baby crabs.

title.children: 'A carpet of red' as millions of baby crabs storm Christmas Island's beaches
